content: This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "REVERSE" option has therefore been deactivated.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: it's very cool

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The code is very straightforward once you figured out the trick

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Looks good to me.

Edited to improve a few formatting details.

In my opinion you need at least 2 more cases such as the 3rd one to make it reasonable for reverse mode (because obviously the 4th case is too large to help, and this case should also probably be moved to the very end to avoid some painful scrolling in reverse mode).

The 4th consideration (about rounding) could also be removed as it's useless and even confusing considering the statement previously explicitly mentions that you're expected to "count the number of transitions".

Cool clash! I have some suggestions, to trim down the instructions leave out the first two "considerations" since they are to be expected. They other two could be combined with the "To compute..." line. To get a better feeling for the clash I tried to get a shortest in ruby:
l=c=-1;gets.to_i.times{x=gets.count(?0)/6;c+=1if x!=l;l=x};p c
Also, dandy name :)

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

I really like this. I agree with Raimon that the problem statement is a bit too long, so try reducing it. The important part seems to be that there's "less errors than valid characters". Definitely emphasize that, since that's a super key part of the algorithm (figuring out if there's a state change between the last line to the current).

+1 Definitely has potential!

edit:
here's python solution:

n = int(input())
lastState = False
stateChanges = 0

for i in range(n):
    line = input()
    isFast = line.count('1') > line.count('0')
    
    if i == 0:
        lastState = isFast
    elif lastState != isFast:
        stateChanges += 1
        lastState = isFast

print(stateChanges)
I like the idea, though i think for CoC this would be well served by reducing the size of the instructions.

Cool.

You should add specific test about the "dendro-errors", to catch people who would not handle these errors correctly. Put it to the limit, with 6 ones and 4 zeros, or 6 zeros and 4 ones.

For example:
"0110101110" must be considered as a ring with ones. But if you only check the first and/or the last character, you miss it.

"0000111111" and "0000001111" may also be interesting to test.

Thank your for your feedback!
Actually the "very old tree" test case was generated randomly but within the limits specified in the statement.
Therefore it includes lines such as :

N(1111Q311
WS111111.U
E11111+1UJ
400+[0000A
011Z111;11

On so on

But I reckon I could add a simpler test first to better demonstrate the idea
You don't need the if statement if stateChanges starts at -1
I have updated the contribution, thank you for your feedback
